qas.question: What is believed to have caused the opening of new sea routes during the Ottoman Empire?

answers.text: change in relations between the Ottoman Turks and central Europe

qas.question: The formation of sea routes bypassing the Middle East may have led to the decline of what?
What is another name for the Treaty of Balta Liman?
What did the Treaty of Balta Liman do for Ottoman markets?

answers.text: opened the Ottoman markets directly to English and French competitors

qas.question: In what direction did land routes lose their importance?

context: Modern Ottoman studies think that the <a0_0>change in relations between the Ottoman Turks and central Europe<a0_0/> was caused by the opening of the new sea routes. It is possible to see the decline in the significance of the land routes to the <a4_0>East<a4_0/> as Western Europe opened the ocean routes that bypassed the Middle East and Mediterranean as parallel to the decline of <a1_0>the Ottoman Empire itself<a1_0/>. <a2_0>The Anglo-Ottoman Treaty<a2_0/>, also known as the Treaty of Balta Liman that <a3_0>opened the Ottoman markets directly to English and French competitors<a3_0/>, would be seen as one of the staging posts along this development.
